Vapor-phase dehydration of 1,3-butanediol to 1,3-butadiene over WO3/SiO2 catalyst Enggah Kurniawan Data curation Visualization Writing – original draft Lingyiming Yu Data curation Visualization Ryo Kobayashi Data curation Takayoshi Hara Data curation Validation Yasuhiro Yamada Supervision Validation Satoshi Sato Conceptualization Methodology Project administration Funding acquisition Writing – review & editing ⁎ Graduate School of Engineering, Chiba University, 1-33 Yayoi, Inage, Chiba 263-8522, Japan Graduate School of Engineering, Chiba University 1-33 Yayoi, Inage Chiba 263-8522 Japan Graduate School of Engineering, Chiba University, 1–33 Yayoi, Inage, Chiba 263–8522, Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. Several silica-supported metal oxides (M x O y /SiO2) were employed as catalysts for 1,3-butadiene (BD) production via the dehydration of 1,3-butanediol (1,3-BDO). Among the M x O y /SiO2 catalysts tested, WO3/SiO2 catalyst showed the most promising activity for BD production. Several parameters, such as reaction temperature, contact time, calcination temperature of the catalyst, and W content in the catalyst, influenced the rate of the first-step dehydration of 1,3-BDO to unsaturated alcohols (UOLs), while only contact time significantly affected the consecutive dehydration of UOLs to BD. The poisoning experiment using 2,6- and 3,5-dimethylpyridine revealed that both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites of the WO3/SiO2 catalyst played an essential role in the dehydration of 1,3-BDO to BD. Under optimum conditions at 300 °C and a contact time of 2.65 h, a BD yield as high as 73.4% was attained. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords 1,3-butanediol 1,3-butadiene Vapor-phase dehydration WO3/SiO2 Solid acid catalyst Dimethylpyridine Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Catalytic transformation of biomass-derived alcohol to 1,3-butadiene (BD), an essential chemical in the rubber and polymer resin industries, is a potential strategy for BD production, considering the demand for BD is steadily growing [1–3]. In addition, the growing concern about the continuous production of BD via naphtha cracking has increased the urgency of a greener and more sustainable strategy for BD production [4–6]. In this regard, catalytic dehydration of biomass-derived alcohol to BD can be considered a viable solution for BD production since biomass utilization is a carbon-neutral and sustainable process. Recent reports have shown green strategies for BD formation from ethanol [7–9] and butanediols (BDOs), such as 1,3-, 2,3-, and 1,4-BDO [10–16]. The ethanol-to-BD (ETB) transformation proceeds via the Lebedev process, in which the BD is generated via multi-step reactions, namely dehydrogenation, aldol condensation, hydrogenation, and dehydration [17–19]. In the last step of ETB process, BD is produced from the dehydration of crotyl alcohol [20,21]. Due to these multi-step transformations, the ETB is considered a complex process, and the choice of catalyst must facilitate different reactions. Furthermore, different types of reactions are prone to cause numerous side reactions that will reduce the yield of the desired product. Meanwhile, the BD production from BDOs, chemicals generated from the microbial conversion of sugar [22–27], proceeds via two consecutive dehydrations in which unsaturated alcohols (UOLs) are generated as the intermediates [10–16]. We have recently reported effective BD production from 1,3-, 2,3-, and 1,4-BDO via an acid-base concerted mechanism, in which the Lewis acid of metal cations and the basic site from O2– species are essential during catalytic dehydration [12–14]. BD production via BDO dehydration is relatively more convenient since this process only requires one type of reaction; as a result, BD yields higher than 80% have been achieved over rare earth oxide and zirconate catalysts [13–15]. A few reports on the efficient production of BD from 2,3- and 1,4-BDO using solid acid catalysts with strong acidity have been published: butanone is majorly formed from 2,3-BDO [28–32], and tetrahydrofuran is selectively produced from 1,4-BDO [33]. Solid acid catalysts have also been reported as catalysts for the dehydration of 1,3-BDO to BD [34,35], in which many by-products are formed ( Scheme 1). Silica-alumina catalysts, in particular, have gained considerable interest due to their activity in 1,3-BDO dehydration [34–40]. Nevertheless, low BD selectivity remains the major issue for BD formation via dehydration of 1,3-BDO [35]. Several silica-alumina catalysts have been reported to give BD yield of < 60% [35,36]. Despite providing high 1,3-BDO conversion, the strong acidity of silica-alumina catalysts often facilitates the side reactions. Recently, Hong et al. reported a highly active H-ferrierite (Si/Al=130) zeolite for BD production using aqueous 1,3-BDO as the feed reactant (H2O/1,3-BDO = 45), with BD yield reaching 71% [38]. However, when anhydrous 1,3-BDO was used as the reactant feed, the conversion of 1,3-BDO and BD selectivity decreased. These results show that the pursuit of a highly efficient catalyst for 1,3-BDO dehydration is still ongoing. Previously, we employed several silica-supported metal oxides (M x O y /SiO2) for the dehydration of crotyl alcohol, i.e., 2-butene-1-ol (2B1OL), to BD [41], with W- and Al-based catalysts show the promising performance for BD production. According to the NH3- and CO2-TPD, the M x O y /SiO2 catalysts contain acid sites without basic properties; therefore, it can be said that the acid sites act as active species in the dehydration of 2B1OL. This finding also suggests that the role of acid sites can be investigated by poisoning experiments using a basic molecule. Supported tungsten oxide has been reported to act as a catalyst in numerous reactions, including alkene epoxidation [42], glycol dehydration [43,44], glycerol dehydration [45], and propene metathesis [46]. Supported WO x catalysts are classified as non-toxic solid acids with numerous advantages, such as strong acidity, remarkable stability in water, hydrogen, and oxygen atmosphere, and excellent reusable performance [47]. Among these properties, the acidity of supported WO x is imperative for dehydration reactions using a solid acid catalyst. WO x species has been reported to increase the density of Brønsted acid sites of SiO2 support [47], which is beneficial for 1,3-BDO dehydration since the dehydration activity of a solid acid catalyst is strongly correlated to their Brønsted acid properties [35,36]. Therefore, supported WO x is a promising candidate for an efficient catalyst in the dehydration of 1,3-BDO to BD. In this work, silica-supported metal oxide (M x O y /SiO2) catalysts were employed as catalysts for the dehydration of 1,3-BDO to BD, with WO3/SiO2 catalyst showing the highest activity and selectivity to BD. Several reaction parameters, such as temperature, contact time, and W content, were investigated to determine the most optimum condition for BD production. The role of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites was revealed in a poisoning experiment using 2,6- and 3,5-dimethylpyridine (2,6- and 3,5-DMP). This work can be viewed as one of the green strategies for an efficient catalytic transformation of biomass-derived 1,3-BDO to BD that offers sustainability and prospect for biomass valorization. 2 Experiment 2.1 Preparation of MxOy/SiO2 catalysts Silica (CARiACT Q-10, specific surface area of 294 m2 g−1) as a catalyst support was supplied by Fuji Silycia Chemical Ltd., Japan. Ammonium metavanadate(V) (NH4VO3), ammonium heptamolybdate tertahydrate ((NH4)6Mo7O24・4 H2O), ammonium metatungstate hydrate ((NH4)6H2W12O40・nH2O), and aluminum nitrate nonahydrate (Al(NO3)3・9 H2O) were purchased from Fujifilm Wako Chemicals, Co., Japan. Niobium(V) ethoxide (Nb(OC2H5)5) and anhydrous 2-propanol were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Co., U.S. Several M x O y /SiO2 catalysts were prepared by the wet impregnation method according to previous literature [41,48]. Silica (Q-10) was soaked in a solution containing a metal salt, where either an ammonium salt or a nitrate was dissolved in distilled water, and an alkoxide was dissolved in anhydrous 2-propanol. Then, the solution with silica was degassed under vacuum in a vacuum dryer at 25 °C to fill the solution into the mesopores of silica. After the solution was kept at an ambient pressure for 15 h, the solvent was removed at 30 – 40 °C under a reduced pressure. The recovered solid was further dried in an atmospheric dryer at 110 °C for 24 h, and finally, the catalyst sample was calcined in air at a prescribe temperature for 3 h. The name of the catalyst is expressed as AM x O y /SiO2–T , where A and T represent M loading in mol% and the calcination temperature, respectively. The M loading, A, was calculated as follows: A = 100 C M C M + C Si where C M and C Si are moles of metal and silicon in the catalyst, respectively. 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction measurement (XRD) was performed on a Miniflex 600 (Rigaku Corp., Japan) using monochromatic Cu Kα (λ = 0.15418 nm), equipped with a D/tex Ultra 250 ID detector. X-ray fluorescence (XRF) measurement for the compositional analysis of WO3/SiO2 samples was performed by EDX-900HS (Shimadzu, Corp., Japan) using a calibration curve method with MoO3 reagent as an internal standard. The thermogravimetry analysis (TG) was performed using Thermoplus 8120E2 (Rigaku Corp., Japan). Prior to the measurement, the sample of 10 mg was pre-heated at 110 °C for 1 h to remove the physisorbed water on the sample. After this heat treatment, the weight change of the sample was monitored while the sample was heated to 900 °C at a heating rate of 5 °C min–1. Temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) of adsorbed NH3 was performed using BELCATII (Microtrac BEL Corp., Japan) with thermal conductivity detector (TCD) to estimate the acidity of catalysts, respectively. The measurement conditions are the following: preheating the sample in He flows at 500 °C for 1 h; adsorption of NH3 at 100 °C for 1 h; desorption temperature controlled from 100 to 800°C at an increment rate of 10 °C min−1. The TCD detector can detect gases such as water and oxygen desorbed from the catalyst. Thus, we also performed a blank TPD experiment for the sample preheated at 500 °C without adsorption of NH3. Original TCD signal profiles of desorbed NH3 as a function of temperature together with the blank TCD signals are shown in Fig. S1. A difference TCD signal between NH3 adsorption and the blank TPD signal was converted to an NH3-TPD profile using the molar sensitivity of NH3. The amount of acid sites was estimated from the integral of the desorption profiles of NH3 up to the desorption temperature of 600 °C. The details of the TPD procedure are described elsewhere [13]. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy using pyridine as a probe molecule and an infrared spectrophotometer (IRAﬃnity-1S, Shimazu Corp.) was conducted to discuss the nature of acid sites. A sample was ground to a fine powder and pressed to form thin disk. Prior to pyridine adsorption, a fresh catalyst was first pretreated in a IR cell at 300 °C under a reduced pressure (ca. 10−3 Pa) for 1 h. After the sample was evacuated at 30 °C for 1 h, a reference spectrum was recorded in the wavenumber range between 400 and 4000 cm−1. Afterward, the sample disk was exposed to pyridine vapor at 30 °C for 0.5 h. After sequential evacuation at 30, 100, 200 and 300 °C for 0.5 h, spectra were recorded at 30 °C. Finally, FT-IR spectra were obtained by subtracting the reference spectrum previously acquired from each acquired spectrum. 2.3 Vapor-phase dehydration of 1,3-BDO to BD Vapor-phase catalytic reaction of 1,3-BDO was carried out in a fixed-bed down-flow glass reactor with an inside diameter of 17 mm in an ambient-pressure N2 flow of 30 cm3 min–1. Prior to the reaction, unless otherwise noted, a catalyst of 0.50 g was pretreated in the N2 flow at the reaction temperature for 1 h. Thereafter, pure 1,3-BDO was fed into the reactor at a feed rate of 1.70 g h–1 (18.9 mmol h–1) together with the N2 carrier gas during the initial time on stream (TOS) of 5 h. The products were collected at 0 °C every 1 h and analyzed by a gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with a flame ionization detector (GC-2014, Shimadzu Corp.) and a capillary column (TC-WAX, 30 m in length, GL-Sciences Inc., Japan). Another GC with a mass spectrometer (QP5050A, Shimadzu Corp.) was used to identify the products. Gaseous products were analyzed by an off-line GC equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (GC-8A, Shimadzu Corp.) and a packed column (VZ-7, 6 m in length, GL-Sciences Inc.) using a gas-tight injection syringe. 2-Pentanol was used as an internal standard for the analysis of liquid products, while the carrier gas of nitrogen was used as an internal standard for the analysis of gaseous products. The conversion of 1,3-BDO and the product selectivity were calculated according to the following equations: Conversion mol % = 1 − mol of recovered reactant mol of the fed reactant × 100 Selectivity mol % = mol of carbon in the specific product × 10000 mol of carbon in the fed reactant × Conversion ( mol % ) Meanwhile, the productivity of BD, P BD, was calculated by the following equation: P BD ( g g - 1 h - 1 ) = 54.09 × Conversion mol % × BD selectivity ( mol % ) 90.12 × W / F × 10000 where 54.09, 90.12, W, and F are the molecular weight of BD and 1,3-BDO, the catalyst weight (g), and the feed rate of 1,3-BDO (g h–1), respectively. Poisoning experiments were performed to clarify the acidic nature related to the catalytic reaction in a similar way to the reaction procedure described above. A poison of either 2,6- or 3,5-DMP was mixed with the reactant 1,3-BDO at a concentration of 4.67 mol%. The mixture together with N2 carrier gas was fed into the reactor at 275 °C. It has been reported that 2,6-DMP selectively poisons Brønsted acid sites, while 3,5-DMP tends to poison both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites [14,49–51]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts screening Fig. S2A shows the time-course profiles of the dehydration of 1,3-BDO over several 2.0 M x O y /SiO2–500 catalysts at a W/F of 0.29 h. During the reaction in the initial 5 h, the conversion decreased with TOS, indicating that the catalysts deactivated. Table 1 lists the average activity for the initial 5 h at 300 °C, except for V2O5/SiO2–500 catalyst, which catalyzed the dehydration at 325 °C. Al2O3/SiO2–500 and WO3/SiO2–500 catalysts gave 1,3-BDO conversion of 94.9% and 91.4% (entries 1 and 2), respectively. Meanwhile, other supported metal oxides, such as Nb2O5/SiO2 and MoO3/SiO2–500 catalysts, had 1,3-BDO conversion below 30% (entries 3 and 4). The 1,3-BDO conversion over V2O5/SiO2–500 catalyst was 31.3%, even though the reaction was carried out at 325 °C (entry 5). Therefore, among the M x O y /SiO2–500 catalysts tested, Al- and W-based catalysts gave the most promising activity for the dehydration of 1,3-BDO. The NH3-TPD analysis has suggested that the M x O y /SiO2–500 catalysts consisted of acid sites with negligible basic sites [41]; thus, it is reasonable to assume that the dehydration of 1,3-BDO proceeded over the acid sites of M x O y /SiO2 catalysts. Previously, we found that the trend of catalytic activity of the M x O y /SiO2–500 catalysts in the dehydration of 2B1OL is not directly proportional to the acid concentration [41]. Similarly, the trend of dehydration of 1,3-BDO to BD in this work did not directly correlate to the acid concentration. Increasing the number of acid sites is not always beneficial for dehydration reactions, and optimum acid sites are also important for an efficient catalytic transformation [47]. Despite having a slightly lower 1,3-BDO conversion, 2.0WO3/SiO2–500 catalyst gave higher BD selectivity than 2.0Al2O3/SiO2 –500 catalyst. The selectivity to propylene (PP) over 2.0Al2O3/SiO2–500 catalyst was significantly higher than that over 2.0WO3/SiO2–500 catalyst. Previous reports have suggested that PP was produced via decomposition of 3-buten-1-ol (3B1OL) [34,38]. Therefore, 2.0Al2O3/SiO2–500 catalyzed the decomposition of 3B1OL to PP more efficiently than 2.0WO3/SiO2–500 catalyst. This assumption is supported by the fact that the 3B1OL selectivity over 2.0Al2O3/SiO2–500 catalyst was lower than that over 2.0WO3/SiO2 catalyst: 3B1OL is less reactive over 2.0WO3/SiO2 than 2.0Al2O3/SiO2 catalyst. In addition, the total selectivity for the side reactions over W-based catalyst was lower than Al-based catalyst under the same reaction conditions. Since the 2.0WO3/SiO2–500 catalyst provided the highest BD selectivity with a significantly smaller rate of side reaction, further investigation of some reaction parameters was conducted using this catalyst. 3.2 Effect of reaction parameters, such as temperature and contact time Fig. 1 A and Table S1 show the effect of reaction temperature on the catalytic activity of 2.0WO3/SiO2–500 catalyst at a short W/F of 0.29 h, and the conversion varied with TOS in the initial 5 h as depicted in Fig. S2B. The conversion of 1,3-BDO and the BD selectivity increased as the reaction temperature increased; however, a significant yield of UOLs remained high even at the highest reaction temperature of 350 °C, i.e., UOLs > 30%. This finding indicates that the first dehydration of 1,3-BDO to UOLs proceeded smoothly at a short W/F, even at a low temperature of 250 °C. Nevertheless, a substantial increment of UOLs dehydration to BD was hardly observed with the increase in reaction temperature at a short W/F, despite a near full conversion of 1,3-BDO. Table S1 indicates that the selectivity to 3B1OL was the highest among UOLs produced from the dehydration of 1,3-BDO, and increasing the reaction temperature gave only a slight decrement in 3B1OL selectivity. On the other hand, the selectivity to 2B1OL and 3-buten-2-ol (3B2OL) was significantly smaller than 3B1OL even at a low reaction temperature of 250 °C, and the increase in reaction temperature further decreased the selectivity to 2B1OL and 3B2OL. These results are in agreement with previous reports, which suggest that 3B2OL and 2B1OL are readily dehydrated to BD, whereas 3B1OL is relatively stable and more difficult to be converted into BD [34,38]. Furthermore, 3B1OL is also prone to decompose into PP, which is less beneficial for BD formation [34,38]. Similar behavior of PP formation was observed in the dehydration of 1,3-BDO over 2.0WO3/SiO2–500 catalyst. Applying a high reaction temperature of 350 °C increased the PP selectivity, while a substantial decrement of 3B1OL was not observed. Therefore, it can be said that increasing the reaction temperature at a short W/F was inefficient in improving BD yield as the dehydration of 3B1OL to BD hardly proceeded. Fig. 1B and Table S2 show the effect of W/F on the catalytic activity of 2.0WO3/SiO2–500 catalyst at 300 °C, while the change in conversion with TOS is shown in Fig. S2C. Full conversion of 1,3-BDO was attained at a W/F of 0.88 h or higher, as shown by the numeric data in Table S2, indicating that the dehydration of 1,3-BDO to UOLs proceeded efficiently. Notably, prolonging the W/F at 300 °C substantially increased the BD selectivity, with a slight increment of PP selectivity. This behavior was also accompanied by a decrease in 3B1OL selectivity. It can be said that the conversion of 3B1OL via dehydration to BD and via decomposition to PP was strongly affected by the W/F. Considering the increment of BD selectivity was higher than that of PP selectivity, prolonging the W/F increased the rate of 3B1OL dehydration more efficiently than the decomposition of 3B1OL to PP. Previously, we have revealed that the BD formation from 3B1OL is still possible [3,12,15], although 3B1OL is relatively stable compared to other UOLs such as 3B2OL and 2B1OL [3,34,38]. Furthermore, the increase in W/F had a negligible effect on the side reactions, as the changes in the selectivity to butanal, 2-butenone, 2-butenal, and 4-methyl-1,3-dioxane were insignificant. In this work, the highest BD yield at 300 °C and a W/F of 2.65 h was 73.4% (Table S2, entry 4). 3.3 Effect of W content and calcination temperature of WO3/SiO2 catalyst Fig. 2A depicts the XRD patterns of the WO3/SiO2–500 catalysts with different W content. The diffraction peaks of the WO3 species are not observed in the XRD profiles of the 1.0WO3/SiO2–500 catalyst, possibly due to the low W content. The increment of the W content to 2 mol% led to the appearance of the peaks associated with WO3 species, which appeared between 2θ of 20–30°. It is obvious that the increment of W content to 4 mol% intensified the peak corresponding to WO3. Fig. 2B is the enlarged diffraction profiles of the AWO3/SiO2–500 catalysts between 2θ of 20–30°. The peaks located between 22° and 25° are indexed to (002), (020), and (200) planes of monoclinic WO3 crystal [43,52–54]. Fig. 3A depicts the NH3-TPD curves of AWO3/SiO2–500 catalysts. Similar to the previous report [47], the NH3 curves are maximized below 300 °C, indicating that the majority of the acid sites is weak acid sites, regardless of the W content. The NH3 uptake of AWO3/SiO2–500 with the W content of 1.0, 2.0, and 4.0 mol% are 0.099, 0.251, and 0.231 mmol g–1, respectively. Since the NH3 uptake of SiO2 support was 0.049 mmol g–1 [41], the addition of W onto SiO2 support clearly increased the acid sites, which is in agreement with the previous report [43,44,47]. It is worth noting that the trend of catalytic activity of the AWO3/SiO2–500 catalysts is similar to that of NH3 uptake. It has been reported that the acid sites act as the active site for the dehydration of 1,3-BDO [34,35]; thus, it is understandable that the catalytic activity of the AWO3/SiO2–500 catalysts follows the trend of acid site concentration. Therefore, the 4.0WO3/SiO2–500 catalyst was inferior to the 2.0WO3/SiO2–500 catalyst due to a lower concentration of acid sites. Fig. S2D shows the change in conversion of AWO3/SiO2–500 catalysts at the TOS of 5 h. Notably, the catalyst showed serious deactivation with TOS. The 2.0WO3/SiO2–500 catalyst with the highest catalytic performance had the best catalytic stability. It is worth noting that the stability of the AWO3/SiO2–500 catalyst follows a similar trend to that of NH3 uptake (Fig. 3A). It can be said that a small amount of coke might severely deactivate the catalyst with a small number of acid sites, leading to rapid catalyst deactivation, as opposed to the catalyst with a higher concentration of acid sites. Table 2 shows the effect of W content on the average activity of the WO3/SiO2–500 catalysts at 300 °C and W/F of 0.29 h. The increment of W content from 1.0 to 2.0 mol% increased the conversion of 1,3-BDO from 29% to 91.4% (entries 1 and 2). In addition, the selectivity to BD also increased from 9.4% to 40.6%. However, further increment of W content from 2.0 to 4.0 mol% decreased the 1,3-BDO conversion and BD selectivity (entry 3). Previous reports have suggested that the number of surface acid sites is affected by the surface coverage of WO x species [55]. Monolayer of WO x existed on the support when the W density was below 5 nm–2, and WO3 nanoparticles will cover the monolayer WO x at W density between 5 and 10 nm–2. Meanwhile, bulk-like WO3 crystals existed when the W density was above 10 nm–2. It should also be noted that the surface acid sites continuously decrease above the monolayer coverage, indicating that the surface acid sites will continue to decrease with the increment of W content after it exceeds the monolayer coverage [55]. In this report, W content of 2 and 4 mol% equal to W density of 4 and 8 nm–2, respectively. It is reasonable to assume that the lower acidity of 4.0WO3/SiO2–500 catalyst than 2.0WO3/SiO2–500 catalyst is due to the difference in surface coverage. The 2.0WO3/SiO2–500 catalyst might have WO x monolayer coverage which provides more acid sites than the 4.0WO3/SiO2–500 catalyst, which has crystalline WO3 covering the monolayer WO x . The correlation between acidity and catalytic activity was further confirmed by the amount of coke deposited on the spent AWO3/SiO2–500 catalysts, as depicted in Fig. 4A. Previous reports have suggested that the acid sites are responsible for the coke formation during the dehydration of alcohols [35,39]. As a result, the catalyst with a higher acid site concentration contained a higher amount of carbonaceous species formed during the reaction. Fig. 1C summarizes the effect of the calcination temperature of 2.0WO3/SiO2 catalyst on the catalytic activity at 300 °C and a W/F of 0.29 h. The conversion of 1,3-BDO varied with TOS, as shown in Fig. S2E. The increase in the calcination temperature from 300 to 500°C increased the 1,3-BDO conversion and BD selectivity, as shown by the numeric data in Table S3. Further increment of the calcination temperature to 600 °C significantly decreased the activity of the 2.0WO3/SiO2 catalyst. Concurrently, the effect of calcination temperature on the catalytic activity was similar to its effect on the acid site concentration of the 2.0WO3/SiO2 catalysts. According to the NH3-TPD shown in Fig. 3B, the NH3 uptake increased when the calcination temperature was raised from 300 to 500°C, and a sharp decline in NH3 uptake was observed when the calcination was further increased to 600 °C. Therefore, it is obvious to assume that the calcination affected the catalytic activity of the 2.0WO3/SiO2 catalysts by affecting their acid site concentration. A similar correlation between calcination temperature, acid properties, and catalytic activity was found in the dehydration of 1,2-propanediol to propanal over the WO3/SiO2 catalyst [43]. In the dehydration of 1,2-propanediol to propanal over WO3/SiO2 catalysts, the appropriate calcination temperature of 320 °C ensures the thermal decomposition of the WO3 precursor and the generation of WO3 species with the highest acid site concentration. Applying a higher calcination temperature is not favorable for 1,2-propanediol dehydration since it decreases the acid site concentration; meanwhile, a lower calcination temperature is inefficient for the thermal decomposition of the WO3 precursor, ammonium metatungstate, to WO3. In this work, the calcination of the 2.0WO3/SiO2 precursor at 300 °C generated amorphous WO3 species as the peaks associated with the WO3 crystal was not observed in the diffractogram (Fig. 2C and D) [43,54]. The NH3 uptake of the 2.0WO3/SiO2–300 was lower than that of the 2.0WO3/SiO2 catalysts calcined at 400 and 500 °C, possibly due to the incomplete thermal decomposition of ammonium metatungstate to WO3 [56]. The peaks associated with WO3 crystal started to emerge when the calcination temperature was 400 °C. In addition, the NH3 uptake of the 2.0WO3/SiO2 catalysts also increased and reached its highest amount when the sample was calcined at 500 °C. Therefore, the growth of the WO3 crystal was favorable for the generation of the acid site in the 2.0WO3/SiO2 catalyst. Further increment of calcination temperature sharpens the peaks belonging to the WO3 crystal, which suggests the increase in WO3 crystallinity. Nevertheless, the NH3 uptake sharply declined, indicating that high calcination temperature led to the aggregation of WO3 crystal which consecutively decreased the acid site concentration. The TG curves of the spent 2.0WO3/SiO2 calcined at 300, 500, and 600 °C are depicted in Fig. 4B. The amount of coke was strongly correlated with the activity and acid concentration. The largest amount of carbonaceous species was found on the catalyst with the highest acid site concentration since the acid sites are responsible for the coke formation. Understandably, the 2.0WO3/SiO2-600 catalyst, which contained the least acid site concentration, generated the least amount of carbonaceous species. The trend of coke formation as a result of varying calcination temperatures is similar to the one caused by W content. These findings further confirm the importance of acid sites in the dehydration of 1,3-BDO to BD over WO3/SiO2 catalysts. 3.4 Role of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites of WO3/SiO2 catalyst We have previously reported that WO3/SiO2 catalyst consisted of acid sites with negligible basic sites [41]. Therefore, the acid sites may act as the sole active species in the dehydration of 1,3-BDO to BD. The role of acid sites, i.e., Lewis or Brønsted acid, can be investigated using 2,6- and 3,5-DMP since 2,6-DMP has been reported to poison Brønsted acid sites, whereas 3,5-DMP poisons Lewis and Brønsted acid sites [14,49–51]. The existence of Brønsted and Lewis acid in 2.0WO3/SiO2–500 catalyst was determined using FT-IR of adsorbed pyridine. Fig. 5 reveals the IR spectra of pyridine adsorbed on 2.0WO3/SiO2–500 catalyst at different temperatures. The characteristic vibration mode of pyridine adsorbed on a Lewis acid site is indicated by the peaks located at a wave number of 1440 cm-1 and 1580 cm-1 [57]. The peak around 1470 – 1500 cm-1 is related to the vibration mode of pyridine on a Lewis acid site, but it can also be ascribed to the vibration mode of pyridinium ion on a Brønsted acid site [58,59]. Meanwhile, a weak signal at 1540 cm-1 might be attributed to the vibration mode of pyridinium ion with a Brønsted acid site [57]. Upon evacuation under vacuum at 100 °C (Fig. 5), the peaks attributed to the Lewis acid sites are substantially weakened. Notably, evacuation at higher temperatures of 200 and 300 °C, the peaks associated with Lewis and Brønsted acid completely disappeared. According to the NH3-TPD curves, the acid sites in 2.0WO3/SiO2–500 catalyst are weak acid sites. Furthermore, previous results have also suggested that the WO3/SiO2 catalysts contains weak Brønsted and Lewis acid [43,44]. Thus, it is reasonable that the evacuation under vacuum condition desorbed the pyridine from the 2.0WO3/SiO2–500 catalyst. Table 3 shows the results of the poisoning experiment using 2,6- and 3,5-DMP in the dehydration of 1,3-BDO over the 2.0WO3/SiO2–500 catalyst at 275 °C and a W/F of 1.7 h. In the absence of 2,6- and 3,5-DMP, 2.0WO3/SiO2–500 catalyst gave 1,3-BDO conversion and BD selectivity of 81.3% and 35.2%, respectively (entry 1). Notably, 3B1OL with the selectivity of 33.1% remained, suggesting that the consecutive dehydration of 3B1OL to BD hardly proceeded at 275 °C and a W/F of 1.7 h. The addition of 2,6-DMP, which can block the Brønsted acid sites, into the reaction system decreased the 1,3-BDO conversion and BD selectivity (Table 3, entry 2). This result indicates that the first step of dehydration of 1,3-BDO to UOLs and the consecutive dehydration of UOLs to BD are hindered when the Brønsted acid sites are poisoned. Nevertheless, the Lewis acid sites are still able to catalyze the dehydration of 1,3-BDO to BD, even though the dehydration rate decreased. Previously we have reported that the Brønsted acid sites of the WO3/SiO2 catalyst act as the active site in the dehydration of 3B2OL and 2B1OL to BD at 200 °C and W/F of 0.31 h, while the Lewis acid sites only catalyze the isomerization of 2B1OL to 3B2OL and give negligible BD under the same reaction conditions [41]. In this work, the presence of Lewis acid sites was still able to generate BD at 275 °C and W/F of 1.7 h. Therefore, it can be assumed that the dehydration of UOLs, including 2B1OL, 3B2OL, and 3B1OL, to BD still proceeds over the Lewis acid sites of 2.0WO3/SiO2–500 catalyst at a higher temperature and a longer W/F. It is also worth noting that the 2.0WO3/SiO2–500 catalyst had a higher deactivation rate in the presence of 2,6-DMP (Fig. S2F). A small amount of coke could severely impact the performance of the 2.0WO3/SiO2–500 catalyst in the presence of 2,6-DMP since the available active sites were hindered by 2,6-DMP and coke, leading to a steep decline in catalytic performance with TOS. The dehydration of 1,3-BDO to BD was further suppressed when 3,5-DMP, which blocks the Brønsted and Lewis acid sites, was added in the reactant of 1,3-BDO. The dehydration of 1,3-BDO to UOLs and the consecutive dehydration of UOLs to BD were severely hindered as the 1,3-BDO conversion was only 26.9% even at the initial 1 h of TOS, with the BD selectivity of 9.9% (Table 3, entry 3). The presence of 3,5-DMP reduced the initial 1,3-BDO conversion (Fig. S2F) because 1,3-BDO was hardly adsorbed on both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites. Table 3 also shows that the selectivity to 3B2OL and 2B1OL was higher than 10% when the Brønsted and Lewis acid sites were blocked by 3,5-DMP. Even though the dehydration of 2B1OL and 3B2OL to BD proceeds at a high rate over solid acid catalysts, the presence of 3,5-DMP reduces the dehydration rate of 2B1OL and 3B2OL. It should also be noted that 2,6- and 3,5-DMP could be periodically recovered in the reaction effluent, even at the shortest TOS of 1 h. Thus, we assumed that competitive adsorption-desorption of DMPs and substrates proceeded during the poisoning experiment. These hindrances to either Lewis and/or Brønsted acid sites via competitive adsorption decreased the rate of dehydration, which suggests the importance of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites in the dehydration of 1,3-BDO to BD. Considering that the 2.0WO3/SiO2–500 catalyst deactivated with TOS of 5 h at 300 °C and a W/F of 0.29 h, we tried to reactivate the catalyst by recalcining the spent 2.0WO3/SiO2–500 catalyst at 500 °C for 3 h to remove the accumulated coke. According to the TG curves (Fig. 4), calcination of spent 2.0WO3/SiO2–500 catalyst in air at 500 °C would be sufficient to remove the coke accumulated on the spent catalyst. After the calcination, the black color of the spent catalyst changed to white, similar to that of fresh one. The reactivated catalyst was then employed for the dehydration of 1,3-BDO under the same conditions as the one in Table 1. Fig. S3 shows the comparison of the catalytic activity of the fresh and reactivated 2.0WO3/SiO2–500 catalysts. The performance of the reactivated catalyst was significantly lower than that of the fresh one. Thus, the coke removal could not recover the activity of the spent catalyst. Fig. S4 reveals the XRD pattern of the reactivated 2.0WO3/SiO2–500 catalyst. Clearly, the peaks associated with the WO3 species were intensified, indicating the agglomeration of the WO3 crystal. Therefore, the decrement of catalytic performance of the reactivated catalyst after the recalcination was due to the aggregation of WO3 species. Table 4 shows the performance of previously reported catalysts in the dehydration of 1,3-BDO to BD. Silica-alumina and acidic zeolites have been reported to facilitate the dehydration of 1,3-BDO to BD; however, their strong acidity often led to a high rate of side reaction and severe catalyst deactivation [38–40]. Several research groups utilized the diluted 1,3-BDO to overcome these issues. Previously, we have reported that Y2Zr2O7 catalyst shows high stability in the dehydration of 1,3-BDO at 375 °C even when pure 1,3-BDO was used as the feed reactant [14]. In addition, Y2Zr2O7, which contains acid and base sites, gives high BD selectivity; nevertheless, the productivity of BD is low. Recently, SiO2-supported heteropoly acid such as H3PW12O40/SiO2, which contains high percentage of Brønsted acid sites, exhibits high initial productivity of BD [39,40]; nevertheless, severe catalyst deactivation observed upon prolonging the TOS during the dehydration of 1,3-BDO. The pore size of silica support might strongly affect the deactivation of silica-supported heteropoly acid similar to that in the dehydration of glycerol [60]. In this work, the BD productivity of the 2.0WO3/SiO2–500 catalyst was comparable to several silica-alumina and acidic zeolite catalysts; however, it is lower than the initial productivity of H3PW12O40/SiO2 possibly due to a significantly lower Brønsted acid site concentration. In summary, the 2.0WO3/SiO2–500 catalyst prepared by simple impregnation protocol served as an efficient catalyst for the production of BD from biomass-derived 1,3-BDO. This work can be viewed as a sustainable strategy to obtain highly desirable chemicals from biomass using abundant, non-toxic supported metal oxide. 4 Conclusion Several silica-supported metal oxides were examined as catalysts in the dehydration of 1,3-BDO to produce BD. WO3/SiO2 catalysts successfully catalyzed the dehydration of 1,3-BDO to BD via the formation of UOLs. The 2.0WO3/SiO2–500 catalyst gave the highest BD selectivity due to a low rate of side reactions. Efficient dehydration of 1,3-BDO to UOLs proceeded even at a short W/F; nevertheless, a long W/F was required to generate BD from UOLs at 300 °C efficiently. Under the optimum conditions at 300 °C and a long W/F of 2.65 h, the highest BD yield of 73.4% was achieved. The evaluation of catalytic performance under several conditions and NH3-TPD analysis indicate that the activity of WO3/SiO2 catalyst was strongly correlated to their acid properties. Furthermore, the acid sites were also responsible for the coke formation as the coke amount was in line with the acid site concentration. The poisoning experiment using 2,6- and 3,5-DMP revealed that both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites played essential roles in the dehydration of 1,3-BDO to BD. coredata.dc:description: Several silica-supported metal oxides (M x O y /SiO2) were employed as catalysts for 1,3-butadiene (BD) production via the dehydration of 1,3-butanediol (1,3-BDO). Among the M x O y /SiO2 catalysts tested, WO3/SiO2 catalyst showed the most promising activity for BD production. Several parameters, such as reaction temperature, contact time, calcination temperature of the catalyst, and W content in the catalyst, influenced the rate of the first-step dehydration of 1,3-BDO to unsaturated alcohols (UOLs), while only contact time significantly affected the consecutive dehydration of UOLs to BD. The poisoning experiment using 2,6- and 3,5-dimethylpyridine revealed that both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites of the WO3/SiO2 catalyst played an essential role in the dehydration of 1,3-BDO to BD. Under optimum conditions at 300 °C and a contact time of 2.65 h, a BD yield as high as 73.4% was attained.
coredata.dc:title: Vapor-phase dehydration of 1,3-butanediol to 1,3-butadiene over WO3/SiO2 catalyst
